item.title: "The Sages Say" Monster Generator
item.description: I made a thing that makes monsters. I’m terribly pleased with it right now, but let me know what you think. If the embed below is giving you weird formatting (on a phone or tablet, say), or if you just want to mess with it, check out the sheet here. I used Brendan’s excellent methodology to build it in Google Sheets. Every time you refresh this page, you should get a new result.

item.title: OSR Classes: The Mastermind and the Rook
item.description: After my last post on Flexible Reaction Rolls, I found myself thinking about how to build Character Classes that fit with the schemey, urban style of play I’m shooting for with Fellhold. The trouble for me until now was that I couldn’t think of ways to get that stuff without impinging on the Old School playstyle I enjoy. What cracked it for me was turning the Reaction Roll into a mechanic with more knobs to play with.

item.title: Money & Equipment in Fellhold
item.description: I don’t know about you, but I find coming up with equipment lists a huge pain in the ass. Coming up with starting equipment packages? Even harder. So why don’t I just use one of the perfectly serviceable equipment lists already out there? Because I definitely buy into the thought that equipment lists are a great way to convey implicit setting and approaches to the game. So I bit the bullet and cranked the below out.

item.title: The Soul Economy in Fellhold
item.description: So, back when I first started rebooting my home campaign setting from a Tentpole Megadungeon generic D&D world that owed a lot to Dwimmermount and into something a little funkier, one of the ideas I hit upon was that the economy would be based on souls. I didn’t really know what that meant, but it seemed cool, so I ran with it. Well, after lots of reading and thinking and coming up with other parts of the world, it finally clicked together into something that makes some (warped, D&D, in-game) sense.

item.title: Memory: Some World Building Notes
item.description: http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--q6aXMxAWGI/VLXhzFJ_U6I/AAAAAAAADB0/dDEMCuIA5jY/s1600/es5s-mage-robe.jpg Okay, so this may or may not be game-related, though I’ve tried to provide a few suggestions, but it’s what I’ve been thinking about recently, and it’s definitely game adjacent if nothing else. I figure smart folks can use interesting stuff in all kinds of ways for games that I can’t even think of. So, I’ve had a long fascination with memory and learning. As part of that, I’ve more-or-less idly poked around at methods of improving my performance in both, but other than a few abortive experiments, I’ve never gotten anywhere spectacular.
